Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Maintenance Dredging Innovations for Coastal Flooding Prevention
Award.AbstractNarration:
Current dredging technologies cause extensive environmental damage, resulting in high project costs for the Army Corps of Engineers, State Departments of Natural Resources, and dredging contractors. As such, this team has designed the "Microdredger" and has been continually conducting customer discovery research, to ensure that its innovations align with the real pains in the marketplace. The "Microdredger" is like the Roomba for waterways. It's an intelligent, robotic system that can continuously and autonomously remove sediment with less environmental disturbance and human involvement. Instead of a root canal once every 10 years, the Microdredger? offers its customers a more regular solution, like brushing your teeth every day. The core values the proposed team offers its customers are reduced environmental impact, including a 90% reduction in fossil fuel consumption and a 50-80% reduction of overall project costs by reducing equipment mobilization and operation costs. As a result, the "Microdredger" has the potential to expand the existing $2.7 billion maintenance dredging market to include waterways that cannot be serviced with traditional dredging technologies obviously helping both the contractors servicing the waterways and the commercial or recreational activity in the waterbody.

This I-Corps team has developed proof-of-concept prototypes to validate various aspects of its technological operations; the team is currently finishing up the development of its beta prototype. At the end of the project, the team expects to be able to present a sound, validated business model from which it can move forward with, in its path to commercialization. The proposed activities, centered around customer discovery and feasibility research, will allow the team the valuable opportunity to explore and test different distribution channels and revenue models, among other aspects, while also connecting to key resources and partners. These activities, guided by expert mentors, give the team the confidence that they will be able to demonstrate a feasible business model and commercialization plan at the close of the project.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two students from engineering and architecture, a business mentor, and an engineering faculty member participated together in the I-Corps program during the spring of 2016 to look at market opportunities in commercializing emerging technology in the space of maintenance dredging for coastal flooding prevention. The technology innovations involve everything from distributed sensing and actuation and robotics to aesthetics and environmental protection. Current dredging technology is decades if not centuries old and causes extensive environmental damage resulting in high project costs for the Army Corps of Engineers, State Departments of Natural Resources, and dredging contractors. The NSF funds for this project were for exploring the potential of disrupting this market through key innovations regarding low to no impact on marine life. The group also worked toward educating the team on the process of going forward with bringing their innovations to market through entrepreneurial pathways.

In terms of the outcomes of this funding, it was an eye-opening experience for the students involved. The customer discovery process put them in direct communication with potential customers where they dealt firsthand with talking to hundreds of customers traveling around the nation over this short period of time. They learned the mechanics of startup formation and the processes of agile and lean management in rapidly growing innovation. They pushed forward with fully developing business plans, executive summaries, and how to present ideas to the business and investment communities. As a result, they formulated a startup and have attracted significant interest winning funds from business plan competitions and achieving potential customer commitments – hallmarks of a successful endeavor. Their success has already motivated other students into looking at creating innovative businesses, competing in innovation and business challenges run through the university, and joining riskier projects through the capstone design sequence. Much of the curriculum material and experiences will be used by the faculty member in advancing the Innovation and Entrepreneurship (I&E) curriculum in the College of Engineering. Another fruitful outcome was the continued push of faculty from the school’s college of engineering to work collaboratively with other colleges to explore innovative multidisciplinary science and engineering projects which could lead to business growth and opportunities for student entrepreneurship locally in the State of Hawaii and nationally.

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2016
Modified by: David Garmire
